chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: This is a download from BBC Learning English. To find out more, visit our website.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: Human bodies are no less incredible. Just think of Olympic swimmers and sprinters. Our bodies work using just the energy provided by what we eat. This means that the human body has to be incredibly efficient, using as little energy as possible to do what it needs to.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: In this programme, we'll be asking exactly how efficient is the human body? We'll be comparing human bodies' performance against each other and against some animals too. And, of course, we'll be learning some new and useful vocabulary as well. But before that, I have a question for you, Roy. Efficiency involves an input and an output. It's about the relationship between the amount of energy coming in – in other words, the food we eat –

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: and the amount of energy going out – the usual movements and activities of day-to-day life. So, according to this definition, which animal is the most efficient? Is it... OK, Roy. I'll reveal the answer later in the programme. To find out more about how the human body works, it's helpful to know how our species

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: evolved. Here's Herman Ponzer, Professor of Evolutionary Anthropology at Duke University, speaking with BBC World Service programme Crowdscience.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: Humans are apes and evolved from the same origin as gorillas and chimpanzees. One big difference, however, is that humans walk upright on straight legs, whereas most animals are crouched – bent over at the knee and leaning forwards to the ground. This crouched posture is not an efficient way to move.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: So, the design of the human body makes it efficient compared to some other animals. But how do humans compare with each other? How do Kenyan athletes break long-distance running records while many of us struggle to run for the bus?

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: University physiologist Rona Pearce is training. But there may be other factors too, as she explained to BBC World Service's Crowdscience.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: Body composition also plays a part.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: And from the evidence, it looks like my answer to your question was right, Sam.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: Well, I'm sorry to say, but that was the wrong answer. The funny thing is – and scientists still don't understand why – but the bigger the animal, the less energy it uses kilo for kilo. So, the most efficient animal… …is also the biggest – a whale! OK, let's recap the vocabulary from the programme.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: Starting with crouched – a position which is bent at the knee, leaning forward and closer to the ground. A dogleg can describe something which has a bent shape, especially a sharp bend in a road or path. The optimal age to do something is the best age to do it. If something drops off, it decreases in quality or quantity. A sweet spot is the best possible combination of factors or circumstances.

chunks.episode_title: Man vs beast_ Who is more efficient_
chunks.chunk_text: And finally, muscle mass is the amount of muscle in your body, as opposed to fat or bone. Once again, our six minutes are up. Bye for now. Bye!
